1ln.title: Arbital requisites
1ln.clickbait: To understand a thing you often need to understand some other things.

1lw.title: Mathematics
1lw.clickbait: Mathematics is the study of numbers and other ideal objects that can be described by axioms.

1lz.title: Bayes' rule
1lz.clickbait: Bayes' rule is the core theorem of probability theory saying how to revise our beliefs when we make a new observation.

1rm.clickbait: What we believed before seeing the evidence.

1rp.title: Posterior probability
1rp.clickbait: What we believe, after seeing the evidence and doing a Bayesian update.

1yd.title: Proof of Bayes's Rule: Intro (Math 1)
1yd.clickbait: Proof of Bayes's Rule, assuming you know the rule itself, and the notations for the quantities involved.
1yd.text:
If you've [1yc read up] on the [1y9 probability notation] used in Bayes's Rule, and understand [1rj conditional probability] and the [1x1 Diseasitis example], we're now ready to prove that the prior odds times the likelihood ratio always equals the posterior odds.

In what follows, $H_i$ and $H_j$ are two competing hypotheses, and $e$ is the evidence.

Bayes's Rule says:

$
\dfrac{\mathbb P(H_i)}{\mathbb P(H_j)}
\cdot 
\dfrac{\mathbb P(e|H_i)}{\mathbb P(e|H_j)} 
= 
\dfrac{\mathbb P(H_i|e)}{\mathbb P(H_j|e)}
$

The quantity $\frac{\mathbb P(H_i)}{\mathbb P(H_j)}$ is the [1rm prior] odds.  E.g., in the Diseasitis problem, dividing 20% by 80% gives us 1/4, which represents the odds ratio (1 : 4).

The quantity $\frac{\mathbb P(e|H_i)}{\mathbb P(e|H_j)}$ is the [1rq likelihood ratio].  For example, in the diseasitis problem, we'd divide $\frac{\mathbb P(positive|sick)}{\mathbb P(positive|\neg sick)}$ to get the number 3, indicating "Sick patients are three times as likely as healthy patients to turn the tongue depressor black."

The quantity $\frac{\mathbb P(H_i|e)}{\mathbb P(H_j|e)}$ is the [1rp posterior] odds.  E.g., in the Diseasitis problem, $\frac{\mathbb P(sick|positive)}{\mathbb P(\neg sick|positive)}$ works out to 3/4 representing the odds ratio (3 : 4).  We indeed have that 1/4 * 3 = 3/4, so the rule is numerically true in this case.

The proof of Bayes's Rule in its general form proceeds by repeatedly applying the definition of conditional probability, $\mathbb P(X|Y) = \frac{\mathbb P(X \wedge Y)}{\mathbb P(Y)}.$

$
\dfrac{\mathbb P(H_i)}{\mathbb P(H_j)} \times  \dfrac{\mathbb P(e|H_i)}{\mathbb P(e|H_j)}
= \dfrac{\mathbb P(e \wedge H_i)}{\mathbb P(e \wedge H_j)}
= \dfrac{\mathbb P(e \wedge H_i) / \mathbb P(e)}{\mathbb P(e \wedge H_j) / \mathbb P(e)}
= \dfrac{\mathbb P(H_i|e)}{\mathbb P(H_j|e)}
$

In the Diseasitis problem, the corresponding quantities would be:

$\dfrac{20\%}{80\%} \times  \dfrac{90\%}{30\%} = \dfrac{18\%}{24\%} = \dfrac{0.18 / 0.42}{0.24 / 0.42} = \dfrac{43\%}{57\%}$

Visualizing the proof graphically:

![bayes venn](https://i.imgur.com/YBc2nYo.png?0)

22s.title: Diseasitis
22s.clickbait: 20% of patients have Diseasitis. 90% of sick patients and 30% of healthy patients turn a tongue depressor black. You turn a tongue depressor black. What's the chance you have Diseasitis?

22w.clickbait: Bayesian problems to try to solve yourself, before beginning to learn about Bayes' rule.

1yd.title: Proof of Bayes's Rule: Intro (Math 1)
1yd.clickbait: Proof of Bayes's Rule, assuming you know the rule itself, and the notations for the quantities involved.
1yd.text:
If you've [1yc read up] on the [1y9 probability notation] used in Bayes's Rule, and understand [1rj conditional probability] and the [1x1 Diseasitis example], we're now ready to prove that the prior odds times the likelihood ratio always equals the posterior odds.

In what follows, $H_i$ and $H_j$ are two competing hypotheses, and $e$ is the evidence.

Bayes's Rule says:

$
\dfrac{\mathbb P(H_i)}{\mathbb P(H_j)}
\cdot 
\dfrac{\mathbb P(e|H_i)}{\mathbb P(e|H_j)} 
= 
\dfrac{\mathbb P(H_i|e)}{\mathbb P(H_j|e)}

The quantity $\frac{\mathbb P(H_i)}{\mathbb P(H_j)}$ is the [1rm prior] odds.  E.g., in the Diseasitis problem, dividing 20% by 80% gives us 1/4, which represents the odds ratio (1 : 4).

The quantity $\frac{\mathbb P(e|H_i)}{\mathbb P(e|H_j)}$ is the [1rq likelihood ratio].  For example, in the diseasitis problem, we'd divide $\frac{\mathbb P(positive|sick)}{\mathbb P(positive|\neg sick)}$ to get the number 3, indicating "Sick patients are three times as likely as healthy patients to turn the tongue depressor black."

The quantity $\frac{\mathbb P(H_i|e)}{\mathbb P(H_j|e)}$ is the [1rp posterior] odds. We indeed have that 1/4 * 3 = 3/4, so the rule is numerically true in this case.

$
\dfrac{\mathbb P(H_i)}{\mathbb P(H_j)} \times  \dfrac{\mathbb P(e|H_i)}{\mathbb P(e|H_j)}
= \dfrac{\mathbb P(e \wedge H_i)}{\mathbb P(e \wedge H_j)}
= \dfrac{\mathbb P(e \wedge H_i) / \mathbb P(e)}{\mathbb P(e \wedge H_j) / \mathbb P(e)}
= \dfrac{\mathbb P(H_i|e)}{\mathbb P(H_j|e)}

![bayes venn](https://i.imgur.com/YBc2nYo.png?0)
